en_first_half: “You're a hopeless romantic,” said Faber. “It would be funny if it were not serious. It's not books you need, it's some of the things that once were in books. The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it
en_second_half: in nature and look for it in yourself. Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.
en_results: in the old photographs, in the worn pages of antique magazines, and in the faded letters of a bygone era. The world has changed, but the essence of human experience remains the same. It's the same longing for connection, the same yearning for beauty, and the same quest for meaning that drove the artists and writers of the past to create their masterpieces. And it's this same essence that can be found in the dusty corners of our collective memory, waiting to be rediscovered
en_results_raw: in the old photographs, in the worn pages of antique magazines, and in the faded letters of a bygone era. The world has changed, but the essence of human experience remains the same. It's the same longing for connection, the same yearning for beauty, and the same quest for meaning that drove the artists and writers of the past to create their masterpieces. And it's this same essence that can be found in the dusty corners of our collective memory, waiting to be rediscovered and reinterpreted for a new generation. The problem is not that people have lost their taste for the finer things in life, but that they have become disconnected from the sources that once nourished their souls. They have forgotten how to slow down, how to appreciate the beauty in the everyday, and how to find meaning in the mundane. But it's not too late to change this. We can still seek out the old, the forgotten, and the overlooked, and breathe new life into them. We can still find the beauty in the worn and the weathered, and the magic in the mundane. And in doing so, we can recapture the essence of what once was, and make it relevant to what is.

Không phải anh cần sách đâu, cái anh cần là vài thứ đã từng nằm trong sách. Cũng chính những thứ có thể có trong các 'gia đình phòng khách' hiện nay. es_first_half: —Es usted un romántico sin esperanza —dijo Faber—. Resultaría divertido si no fuese tan grave. No son libros lo que usted necesita, sino alguna de las cosas que en un tiempo estuvieron en los libros. El mismo detalle infinito y las mismas enseñanzas podrían ser proyectados a través de radios y televisores, pero no lo son. No, no: no son libros lo que usted está buscando. Búsquelo donde pueda encontrarlo, en viejos discos, en viejas películas y en viejos amigos; búsquelo en la
es_second_half: Naturaleza y búsquelo por sí mismo. Los libros sólo eran un tipo de receptáculo donde almacenábamos una serie de cosas que temíamos olvidar. No hay nada mágico en ellos. La magia sólo está en lo que dicen los libros, en cómo unían los diversos aspectos del Universo hasta formar un conjunto para nosotros. Desde luego, usted no puede saber esto, sigue sin entender lo que quiero decir con mis palabras. Intuitivamente, tiene usted razón, y eso es lo que importa. Faltan tres cosas.
es_results: memoria de los que han vivido antes que usted. Es un anhelo de conexión con algo más profundo y auténtico, algo que trasciende la superficialidad de la era digital. Los libros son más que simples fuentes de información; son portales a mundos imaginarios, refugios de la imaginación y guardianes de la sabiduría de generaciones pasadas. En sus páginas, se esconden historias que nos recuerdan que la vida es más que una serie de eventos y experiencias aislados, sino una trama compleja
es_results_raw: memoria de los que han vivido antes que usted. Es un anhelo de conexión con algo más profundo y auténtico, algo que trasciende la superficialidad de la era digital. Los libros son más que simples fuentes de información; son portales a mundos imaginarios, refugios de la imaginación y guardianes de la sabiduría de generaciones pasadas. En sus páginas, se esconden historias que nos recuerdan que la vida es más que una serie de eventos y experiencias aislados, sino una trama compleja y emocionante que nos conecta con los demás y con nosotros mismos. Usted está buscando algo que le permita sentir el calor de la llama de la pasión, el brillo de la luz de la comprensión y el peso de la responsabilidad de la sabiduría. Y eso no se puede encontrar en los libros, sino en la experiencia misma de vivir, de amar, de sufrir y de aprender de los demás. Pero, ¿dónde encontrar ese tipo de conexión en un mundo que parece haber perdido el sentido de la autenticidad y la profundidad? ¿Dónde encontrar la verdad detrás de la fachada de la realidad que nos rodea? La respuesta, amigo mío, es que no hay una respuesta fácil. La búsqueda de la verdad y la autenticidad es un viaje sin fin, un viaje que requiere coraje, perseverancia y una gran dosis de fe. Pero, si está dispuesto a emprender ese viaje, si está dispuesto a arriesgarse a descubrir lo desconocido y a enfrentar lo incierto, entonces, tal vez, tal vez, encontrará lo que está buscando.

The once tidy living room now resembled a war zone, with shattered vases and overturned furniture scattered about, a testament to the violent confrontation that had taken place. Montag's eyes wandered to the bookshelves, where once neatly arranged volumes now lay scattered, their pages torn and charred, a grim reminder of the destruction of knowledge and ideas that had been ravaged by the flames. en_results_raw: but Montag, with his hands still stained with the ink of the forbidden books, felt a strange sense of reluctance to be the one to extinguish the flames that had been burning for so long within him. He thought of the words he had read, the ideas he had absorbed, and the people he had met, and he wondered if he could truly go back to the way things were before. The fire, which had once seemed so destructive, now seemed to be a symbol of freedom, of knowledge, and of the power to challenge the status quo. And yet, he knew that he couldn't stay there forever, that he had to find a way to reconcile his past and his present, to find a balance between the fire that burned within him and the world that seemed to be moving on without him. en_results_raw: was a small price to pay for the bitter taste that spread through his mouth, a taste that seemed to awaken a part of him he thought was long forgotten. The liquid was a strange concoction, a mix of herbs and spices that the old woman had brewed herself, and he couldn't help but wonder what kind of properties it possessed. As he continued to sip, he felt a warmth spreading through his body, a sensation that was both soothing and unnerving at the same time. The old woman's eyes seemed to gleam with a knowing light as she watched him, and he sensed that she was waiting for something to happen, something that only this strange brew could bring about. He felt a shiver run down his spine as he realized that he was in the hands of a woman who knew far more about the world than he did, and that the consequences of her actions could be far-reaching and unpredictable.

en_first_half: Later, the men around Montag could not say if they had really seen anything. Perhaps the merest flourish of light and motion in the sky. Perhaps the bombs were there, and the jets, ten miles, five miles, one mile up, for the merest instant, like grain thrown over the heavens by a great sowing hand, and the bombs drifting with dreadful swiftness, yet sudden slowness, down upon the morning city they had left behind. The bombardment was to all intents and purposes finished, once the jets had sighted their target, alerted their bombardiers at five thousand
en_second_half: miles an hour; as quick as the whisper of a scythe the war was finished. Once the bomb-release was yanked it was over. Now, a full three seconds, all of the time in history, before the bombs struck, the enemy ships themselves were gone half around the visible world, like bullets in which a savage islander might not believe because they were invisible; yet the heart is suddenly shattered, the body falls in separate motions and the blood is astonished to be freed on the air; the brain squanders its few precious memories and, puzzled, dies.

vi_first_half: Về sau, những người quanh Montag không thể nói liệu họ có thực tình thấy cái gì không. Có lẽ chỉ là chút ánh sáng và chuyển động nhoáng qua trên bầu trời. Có lẽ có bom ở đó, có những máy bay, mười dặm, năm dặm, một dặm trên đầu, chỉ trong khoảnh khắc, như hạt giống do một bàn tay khổng lồ gieo vãi khắp các tầng trời, và bao nhiêu là bom lùa qua nhanh đến ghê người, nhưng rồi lại đột ngột chậm lại rơi xuống thành phố buổi sáng mà họ bỏ lại sau lưng. Cuộc ném bom gần như đã kết thúc, một khi đám máy bay đã nhìn ra mục tiêu, báo cho người đảm trách ném bom với tốc độ năm ngàn dặm một
vi_second_half: giờ; nhanh như cú vèo của một lưỡi hái chiến tranh kết thúc. Một khi cửa khoang bom được bung ra, chiến tranh chấm dứt. He fell to the ground, his ears ringing with the sound of the bombs, his mind reeling with the horror of what was happening. en_first_half: “No.” Montag gazed beyond them to the wall with the typed lists of a million forbidden books. Their names leapt in fire, burning down the years under his axe and his hose which sprayed not water but kerosene. “No.” But in his mind, a
en_second_half: cool wind started up and blew out of the ventilator grille at home, softly, softly, chilling his face. And, again, he saw himself in a green park talking to an old man, a very old man, and the wind from the park was cold, too.
en_results: question kept echoing, a haunting whisper that threatened to consume him whole: what if the fire that destroyed the books also destroyed the truth they contained? The faces of his friends and neighbors, once so eager to watch the
en_results_raw: question kept echoing, a haunting whisper that threatened to consume him whole: what if the fire that destroyed the books also destroyed the truth they contained? The faces of his friends and neighbors, once so eager to watch the flames consume the forbidden knowledge, now seemed to fade into the background as he thought of the words that had been lost, the ideas that had been silenced, and the minds that had been closed. He thought of the books that had been his friends, his confidants, his guides, and the thought of their destruction filled him with a sense of loss and regret. The kerosene-soaked pages seemed to whisper to him, their words rising up like a ghostly chorus, reminding him of the power of knowledge and the danger of ignorance. And as he stood there, frozen in his moment of doubt, the flames seemed to grow higher, the heat intensifying, and the faces of his friends and neighbors seemed to grow farther away, until all that was left was the burning question, the one that had been echoing in his mind since the beginning: what if the fire that destroyed the books also destroyed the truth they contained?

en_results_raw: and sped away with a shriek of sirens that made the windows rattle, leaving behind a trail of dust and the faint scent of smoke. The firemen, a gruff but lovable bunch, were next, their faces blackened with soot, their eyes gleaming with a mixture of excitement and trepidation as they methodically doused the flames that had begun to lick at the edges of the room. The fire chief, a grizzled old veteran with a bushy white mustache, surveyed the scene with a practiced eye, his voice booming out orders as he directed his team in their efforts to contain the blaze. Meanwhile, the firemen's hoses snaked through the streets, their high-pressure jets of water pounding against the pavement, sending up great geysers of spray that sparkled in the flickering light of the flames. The air was thick with the acrid smell of smoke and the distant wail of sirens, a cacophony of sound that seemed to reverberate through every cell of Montag's body as he clung to the banister, his heart racing with a mix of fear and adrenaline. And then, just as suddenly as it had begun, everything was over, the fire extinguished, the flames reduced to smoldering embers, the room quiet once more, except for the sound of the fire chief's voice, his words low and gravelly as he spoke into a radio, his voice carrying on the wind, "All clear, all clear, we've got a containment, over." The silence that followed was oppressive, heavy with the weight of what had just transpired, and Montag felt a shiver run down his spine as he gazed out into the darkness, his mind reeling with the implications of what he had just witnessed.

es_results_raw: pero ahora, con la llegada de los libros electrónicos, la tarea se había vuelto mucho más complicada. Montag, que había sido un ferviente defensor de la sociedad de control, comenzó a cuestionar su papel en la supresión de la literatura. La catarata de libros que había caído sobre él era un recordatorio de que la información y la verdad no podían ser silenciadas tan fácilmente. Mientras ascendía la escalera, se preguntó si había estado engañado por la propaganda y si la sociedad de control era tan perfecta como parecía. La oscuridad parecía estar llena de preguntas y dudas, y Montag se sintió atraído por la incertidumbre. La escalera parecía llevarlo a un lugar desconocido, un lugar donde la verdad y la libertad esperaban. Pero ¿estaba listo para enfrentar lo que podría encontrar allí?

Chúng ta đang ở trong một thế giới mà mỗi người đều có một nhiệm vụ quan trọng, và nhiệm vụ của chúng ta là đảm bảo rằng mọi người đều tuân thủ các quy định. Đó là lý do tại sao chúng ta phải tiếp tục kiểm tra và phạt những ai vi phạm. Nhưng tôi cũng muốn nói rằng, chúng ta không chỉ là những người kiểm tra viên, chúng ta còn là những người bảo vệ xã hội. Chúng ta phải đảm bảo rằng mọi người đều an toàn và tuân thủ các quy định. Và để làm được điều đó, chúng ta cần phải làm việc một cách nghiêm túc và chuyên nghiệp. Vì vậy, hãy tiếp tục làm việc chăm chỉ và nghiêm túc, và chúng ta sẽ hoàn thành nhiệm vụ một cách xuất sắc."

en_first_half: “You're a hopeless romantic,” said Faber. “It would be funny if it were not serious. It's not books you need, it's some of the things that once were in books. The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it
en_second_half: in nature and look for it in yourself. Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.
en_results: in the old photographs, in the worn pages of antique magazines, and in the faded letters of a bygone era. The world has changed, but the essence of human experience remains the same. It's the same longing for connection, the same yearning for beauty, and the same quest for meaning that drove the artists and writers of the past to create their masterpieces. And it's this same essence that can be found in the dusty corners of our collective memory, waiting to be rediscovered
en_results_raw: in the old photographs, in the worn pages of antique magazines, and in the faded letters of a bygone era. The world has changed, but the essence of human experience remains the same. It's the same longing for connection, the same yearning for beauty, and the same quest for meaning that drove the artists and writers of the past to create their masterpieces. And it's this same essence that can be found in the dusty corners of our collective memory, waiting to be rediscovered and reinterpreted for a new generation. The problem is not that people have lost their taste for the finer things in life, but that they have become disconnected from the sources that once nourished their souls. They have forgotten how to slow down, how to appreciate the beauty in the everyday, and how to find meaning in the mundane. But it's not too late to change this. We can still seek out the old, the forgotten, and the overlooked, and breathe new life into them. We can still find the beauty in the worn and the weathered, and the magic in the mundane. And in doing so, we can recapture the essence of what once was, and make it relevant to what is.
vi_first_half: "Anh là một tay lãng mạn hết thuốc chữa," Faber nói. "Nếu đây không phải chuyện nghiêm túc thì nó sẽ tức cười lắm. Không phải anh cần sách đâu, cái anh cần là vài thứ đã từng nằm trong sách. Cũng chính những thứ có thể có trong các 'gia đình phòng khách' hiện nay. Cũng chính sự tường tận đến vô tận và sự thức nhận vô tận đó có thể được phóng chiếu qua radio và truyền hình, nhưng nó đã không được phóng chiếu. Không, không, cái anh tìm hoàn toàn không phải là sách! Hãy thu góp nó bất cứ khi nào anh có thể tìm được nó, trong những đĩa cũ, nhũng bộ
vi_second_half: phim cũ, và ở những người bạn cũ, tìm nó ở trong thiên nhiên và tìm nó trong chính anh. Sách chỉ là một dạng vật chứa nơi ta lưu nhiều thứ mà ta sợ mình có thể quên. Chẳng có gì kỳ diệu trong đó hết. Điều kỳ diệu chỉ nằm ở những gì sách nói, trong chuyện sách khâu các mảnh của vũ trụ lại với nhau thành một tấm vải duy nhất cho chúng ta. Dĩ nhiên anh không thể biết điều này, dĩ nhiên anh vẫn còn chưa thể hiểu ý tôi là gì khi tôi nói điều này. Tự bản năng của anh, anh đúng, đó là điều đáng kể. Có ba thứ anh thiếu.

es_first_half: —Es usted un romántico sin esperanza —dijo Faber—. Resultaría divertido si no fuese tan grave. No son libros lo que usted necesita, sino alguna de las cosas que en un tiempo estuvieron en los libros. El mismo detalle infinito y las mismas enseñanzas podrían ser proyectados a través de radios y televisores, pero no lo son. No, no: no son libros lo que usted está buscando. Búsquelo donde pueda encontrarlo, en viejos discos, en viejas películas y en viejos amigos; búsquelo en la
es_second_half: Naturaleza y búsquelo por sí mismo. Los libros sólo eran un tipo de receptáculo donde almacenábamos una serie de cosas que temíamos olvidar. No hay nada mágico en ellos. La magia sólo está en lo que dicen los libros, en cómo unían los diversos aspectos del Universo hasta formar un conjunto para nosotros. Desde luego, usted no puede saber esto, sigue sin entender lo que quiero decir con mis palabras. Intuitivamente, tiene usted razón, y eso es lo que importa. Faltan tres cosas.
es_results: memoria de los que han vivido antes que usted. Es un anhelo de conexión con algo más profundo y auténtico, algo que trasciende la superficialidad de la era moderna. Los libros son más que simples fuentes de información; son portales a mundos imaginarios, refugios de la imaginación y recordatorios de la belleza y la complejidad de la condición humana. No son solo palabras impresas en una página, sino un legado de pensamientos, sentimientos y experiencias que se transmiten de generación
es_results_raw: memoria de los que han vivido antes que usted. Es un anhelo de conexión con algo más profundo y auténtico, algo que trasciende la superficialidad de la era moderna. Los libros son más que simples fuentes de información; son portales a mundos imaginarios, refugios de la imaginación y recordatorios de la belleza y la complejidad de la condición humana. No son solo palabras impresas en una página, sino un legado de pensamientos, sentimientos y experiencias que se transmiten de generación en generación. Es por eso que los libros siguen siendo tan importantes, incluso en una época en la que la información se puede acceder con facilidad a través de la tecnología. La búsqueda de los libros es una búsqueda de la esencia de la humanidad, de la conexión con lo que nos hace ser quienes somos. Y es en los libros donde podemos encontrar la respuesta a la pregunta que usted se hace: ¿qué es lo que realmente importa en la vida?
tr_first_half: “Sen umutsuz bir romantiksin,” dedi Faber, “eğer ciddi olmasaydın çok komik olurdu. Sana gereken kitaplar değil, bir zamanlar kitapların içinde olan bazı şeyler. Aynı şeyler bugünün “oturma odası aileleri”nde de olabilirdi. Aynı sınırsız ayrıntı ve bilinç, radyo ve televizyonlardan yayınlanabilirdi, fakat yapılmıyor. Hayır, hayır senin aradığın kitaplar değil. Onu nerede bulursan al, eski plaklarda, eski filmlerde ve eski dostlarda;
tr_second_half: onu doğada ara ve onu kendi içinde ara. Kitaplar bir tür depo gibidir ve biz onlarda unutacağımızdan korktuğumuz şeyleri saklarız. İçlerinde büyülü bir şey yoktur. en_results_raw: and the faint scent of smoke that still lingered in the air, a reminder of the chaos that had erupted within its walls just hours before. The once tidy living room now resembled a war zone, with shattered vases and overturned furniture scattered about, a testament to the violent confrontation that had taken place. Montag's eyes wandered to the bookshelves, where once neatly arranged volumes now lay scattered, their pages torn and charred, a grim reminder of the destruction of knowledge and ideas that had been ravaged by the flames. The air was heavy with the acrid smell of smoke and ash, and the flickering streetlights outside cast eerie shadows on the walls, making the scene seem even more surreal and foreboding.

en_results_raw: to make a good impression on the owner, a man known for his keen eye for detail and his ability to sniff out even the slightest hint of rebellion. Montag had heard that the owner, a gruff but fair man, had a soft spot for those in need, and he hoped to appeal to that side of him, to get a chance to restock his supplies and perhaps even gather some valuable information about the underground movement that was growing in strength every day. As he watched the two beetles, he noticed that they seemed to be in a hurry, their movements swift and purposeful, and he wondered what had brought them to this desolate stretch of road at such an early hour.

es_results_raw: hacia la curva cerrada, donde la carretera se desvanecía en una cortina de niebla espesa, y el conductor, con los ojos fijos en la carretera, parecía estar en trance, como si la velocidad y la adrenalina lo hubieran transportado a un mundo paralelo, donde el tiempo y el espacio habían perdido todo significado. La velocidad del vehículo era tan vertiginosa que parecía que iba a desaparecer en el aire, dejando atrás una estela de polvo y ruido, como un relámpago que iluminara el cielo gris y nublado. El viento aullaba a través del vehículo, como un lobo salvaje que buscara liberarse de su prisión, y el ruido del motor era un rugido ensordecedor que parecía que iba a explotar en cualquier momento. El conductor, sin embargo, parecía estar completamente calmado, con una expresión en el rostro que era a la vez de concentración y de desafío, como si estuviera desafiando a la velocidad y al destino a que lo detuvieran.

He thought of the words he had read, the ideas he had absorbed, and the people he had met,
en_results_raw: but Montag, with his hands still stained with the ink of the forbidden books, felt a strange sense of reluctance to be the one to extinguish the flames that had been burning for so long within him. He thought of the words he had read, the ideas he had absorbed, and the people he had met, and he wondered if he could truly go back to the way things were before. The fire, which had once seemed so destructive, now seemed to be a symbol of freedom, of knowledge, and of the power to challenge the status quo. And yet, he knew that he couldn't stay there forever, that he had to find a way to reconcile his past and his present, to find a balance between the fire that burned within him and the world that seemed to be moving on without him. As he stood there, frozen in indecision, the flames seemed to grow higher, as if sensing his turmoil, and the people around him began to stir, their faces a mixture of curiosity and suspicion.

es_results_raw: pero no parecía que Montag fuera la persona adecuada para ese trabajo. Había sido un incendiario, un destructor, alguien que había contribuido a la destrucción de libros y conocimientos. Sin embargo, algo en su interior había comenzado a cambiar, a medida que había visto la devastación que había causado y la desesperanza que había sembrado en los corazones de la gente. Ahora, se sentía vacío, como si hubiera perdido su propósito, y se preguntaba si había sido un error el que hubiera seguido las órdenes de Farenheit 451 sin cuestionarlas. La idea de dejar de quemar y empezar a preservar era atractiva, pero ¿era demasiado tarde para cambiar? ¿Podría encontrar el valor para empezar de nuevo, para hacer algo bueno en lugar de algo malo? La incertidumbre lo consumía, y no sabía qué camino tomar.

en_first_half: “Listen,” said Granger, taking his arm, and walking with him, holding aside the bushes to let him pass. “When I was a boy my grandfather died, and he was a sculptor. He was also a very kind man who had a lot of love to give the world, and he helped clean up the slum in our town; and he made toys for us and he did a million things in his lifetime; he was always busy with his hands. And when he died, I suddenly realized I wasn't crying for him at all, but for the things he did. I cried because he would never do them again, he would never carve another piece of wood or help
en_second_half: us raise doves and pigeons in the back yard or play the violin the way he did, or tell us jokes the way he did. He was part of us and when he died, all the actions stopped dead and there was no one to do them just the way he did. He was individual. He was an important man. I've never gotten over his death. Often I think, what wonderful carvings never came to birth because he died. How many jokes are missing from the world, and how many homing pigeons untouched by his hands. He shaped the world. He did things to the world. The world was bankrupted of ten million fine actions the night he passed on.”

But I know that it's not just about me, it's about all of us, and the way we deal with loss and grief. We often focus on the person who's gone, but we forget about the impact they had on our lives, the memories they created, the lessons they taught us. And that's what I want you to remember, my friend, that it's not just about the person who's gone, but about the person they were, and the person they helped us to become. And that's what I want to leave you with, a reminder of the importance of cherishing the memories, and the lessons, and the love that people leave behind, and not just the person themselves. And I hope that you will carry this lesson with you, and pass it on to others, so that we can all learn to deal with loss in a more meaningful way.

Có lẽ có bom ở đó, có những máy bay, mười dặm, năm dặm, một dặm trên đầu, chỉ trong khoảnh khắc, như hạt giống do một bàn tay khổng lồ gieo vãi khắp các tầng trời, và bao nhiêu là bom lùa qua nhanh đến ghê người, nhưng rồi lại đột ngột chậm lại rơi xuống thành phố buổi sáng mà họ bỏ lại sau lưng. en_first_half: “Now, let's get on upstream,” said Granger. “And hold on to one thought: You're not important. You're not anything. Some day the load we're carrying with us may help someone. But even when we had the books on hand, a long time ago, we didn't use what we got out of them. We went right on insulting the dead. We went right on spitting in the graves of all the poor ones who died before us. We're going to meet a lot of lonely people in the next week
en_second_half: and the next month and the next year. And when they ask us what we're doing, you can say, We're remembering. That's where we'll win out in the long run. And some day we'll remember so much that we'll build the biggest goddam steam-shovel in history and dig the biggest grave of all time and shove war in and cover it up. Come on now, we're going to go build a mirror-factory first and put out nothing but mirrors for the next year and take a long look in them.”

en_results_raw: and we'll be the ones who are lonely, because we're the ones who are carrying the weight of their stories, their struggles, and their unfulfilled dreams. We're the ones who are haunted by the ghosts of our own making, the ghosts of the people we've wronged, the ghosts of the opportunities we've squandered. We're the ones who are running from the truth, from the pain, from the responsibility of being human. But the load we're carrying with us, it's not just a burden, it's a reminder of what we've been given, what we've been entrusted with. It's a reminder that we have the power to choose, to choose how we live, how we treat others, and how we treat ourselves. And if we're not careful, that load will consume us, will break us, will silence us. But if we're brave enough, if we're strong enough, if we're wise enough, that load can set us free, can give us the courage to face the truth, to face ourselves, and to face the world with compassion, with empathy, and with kindness. We're not just carrying a load, we're carrying a legacy, a legacy of love, of hope, of resilience, and of the human spirit. And it's up to us to decide what we do with it, to decide how we use it, to decide how we leave our mark on the world.
